content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="4 F e, solid, plus 3 O 2, gas, react to produce 2 F e 2 O 3, solid. delta H naught equals, negative 1650 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> Δ</mtext><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1650</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

A student investigates a reaction used in hand warmers, represented above. The student mixes <math alttext="F e, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with a catalyst and sand in a small open container. The student measures the temperature of the mixture as the reaction proceeds. The data are given in the following table.

Time (min)
 Temperature of Mixture<math alttext="(in degrees Celsius)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="22.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="25.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="34.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>34.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="37.3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="39.7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39.7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="39.4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The mixture (<math alttext="F e, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, catalyst, and sand) has a total mass of <math alttext="15.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and a specific heat capacity of <math alttext="0.72 joule per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.72</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the amount of heat absorbed by the mixture from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes to <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

<math alttext="4 F e, solid, plus 3 O 2, gas, react to produce 2 F e 2 O 3, solid. delta H naught equals, negative 1650 kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext> Δ</mtext><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>1650</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

A student investigates a reaction used in hand warmers, represented above. The student mixes <math alttext="F e, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> with a catalyst and sand in a small open container. The student measures the temperature of the mixture as the reaction proceeds. The data are given in the following table.

Time (min)
 Temperature of Mixture<math alttext="(in degrees Celsius)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="22.0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>22.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="25.1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>25.1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="34.6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>34.6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="37.3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>37.3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="39.7" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39.7</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="39.4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>39.4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The mixture (<math alttext="F e, solid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, catalyst, and sand) has a total mass of <math alttext="15.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.4em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and a specific heat capacity of <math alttext="0.72 joule per gram degree Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.72</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Calculate the amount of heat absorbed by the mixture from <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes to <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> minutes.

(b) Calculate the mass of <math alttext="F e, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Fe</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, in grams, that reacted to generate the amount of heat calculated in part (a).

(c) In a second experiment, the student uses twice the mass of iron as that calculated in part (b) but the same mass of sand as in the first experiment. Would the maximum temperature reached in the second experiment be greater than, less than, or equal to the maximum temperature in the first experiment? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
